refsDecl.p: For infomation on attribues and values.

div.ab: Another ciull warre doe I finde will fall betweene plaiers who albeit at the beginning of this fatal yeare, they salute one another like sworne brothers, yet before the middle of it, shall they with one anothers throat cut for two pence. The contention of the two houses, (the Gods be thanked) was appeased long agoe, but a deadly war betweene these three houses will I feare burst out like thunder and lightning. For it is thought, that flag will be aduanced (as it were in mortall defiance against flag) numbers of people will also be mustered and fall to one side or other, the drums and trumpets must be sounded, parts will then euen by the chiefest players bee taken: words will passe to and fro, speeches cannot so be put vp, hands will walke, an Alarum be giuen, fortune must favour some, or else they are neuer able to stand: the whole world must stick to others, or els all the water in the theames will not serue to carry those away that will be put to flight, and a third faction must fight like wilde buls against Lions , or else it will be in vaine to march vp into the field.

The allusions are probably to the Fortune, Globe and Red Bull playhouses. At sig B2v, Dekker refers to 'the two penny gallerie in a Play-house.' Little is known of the early life of Thomas Dekker (c 1572–c 1632), though he was probably a Londoner, with a first reference in 1598, when he was writing plays for Philip Henslowe. He was apparently perpetually in financial difficulties, and at least twice in prison for debt. As well as writing plays for Worcester’s and Chamberlain’s Men and Paul’s Children, he published a series of pamphlets, and collaborated with other playwrights.

PROLOGVE
The Charmes of silence through this Square be throwne,
That an vn-vsde Attention (like a Iewell)
May hang at euery eare, for wee present
Matter aboue the vulgar Argument:
So, winged Time that long agoe flew hence
You must fetch backe,
There hold it but two howres, It shall from Graues
Raize vp the dead: vpon this narrow floore
Swell vp an Ocean, (with an Armed Fleete,)
sig G3v*
Plain. Stay father, now the Armie comes forward: shee takes downe the flagge, belike their play is done

The prologue and text probably describe the playhouse and the performance, ie, a square building, with a narrow stage, and a play lasting two hours, after which the flag, flying to signify a performance, was taken down.

Thou Barmy Foole, at last grow wise,
Build thy House round with Galleries,
Like to a Play-house; for thy Ale
(Bee’t bad, bee’t good, beet new, bee’t Stale)
Brings thee good Audience: from each those,
Ships of Fooles lanch, to seeke thy Dore;
Ere prodigall Gulls saile backe agen,
Thei’le pay thee money to come in:
Keepe then, thy wife and thou, the dozes,
Let those within wipe out the Scores.
Yet (O vile counsel!) why do I labour
To haue a Christian wrong his neighbour?
Each afternoone thy House being full,
Makes Fortune blind, or Gelds The Bull.
The writer describes how people flocked to Hoxton (ie, Hogsden), in the parish of Shoreditch, where the popularity of Pimlico ales caused audiences to desert the Fortune and Red Bull playhouses.

body.head: sigs E3–E3v ( Globe, Fortune, and Curtain playhouses)

div.ab:
Epigram 39
In Momum.
MOmus would act the fooles part in a play,
And cause he would be exquisite in that way,
Hies
Hies Hies: also printed as a catchword at the foot of E3
me to London, where no day can passe,
But that some play-house still his presence has.
Now at the Globe with a judicious eye,
Into the Vice’s action doth he prie.
Next to the Fortune, where it is a chaunce,
But he mark’s something worth his cognisance.
Then to the Curtaine, where, as at the rest,
He notes that action downe that likes him best.

head.title: Middleton and Dekker, The Roaring Girle

ab.hi: As it hath lately beene Acted on the Fortune- stage

div.ab: sig A4* (Prologue)

A Roaring Girl (whose notes till now neuer were)
Shall fill with laughter our uast Theater
sig Lv* (Play text)
Mol. one of them is a nip; I tooke him once i' the two-penny gallery at The Fortune;

Thomas Middleton (c 1570–1627) was probably born in London and entered Gray’s Inn in 1593 or 1596. But by 1602 he was writing for Philip Henslowe, at the same time working for Paul’s Children. From about 1607 he wrote pageants for the City, and plays for various London livery companies and then in the 1620s for Prince Charles’s Men. In 1624 he was summoned before the Privy Council for his
Game of Chess (TNA: PRO PC2/32, pp. 424–5). A reference in the Prologue (sig A4) to ‘our uast Theater,’ suggests that the Fortune was of a considerable size.

Qui quondam Lixa, Lanista. QuiLanista: 'He who was once a sutler, is (now) a trainer'
Tis said that Whittington was rais'd of nought,
And by a Cat, hath diuers wonders wrought;
But Fortune (not his Cat) makees it appeare:
He may dispend a thousand markes a yeare.
The reference to ‘ Fortune’ is probably to the playhouse.

body.head: sigs C4v–D (9 March) ( Fortune and Red Bull playhouses)

div.ab:
Trincalo. O 'tis Armellina : now if she haue the wit to beginne, as I meane shee should, then will I confound her with complements drawne
drawne drawne: also printed as a catchword at the foot of C4v from the Plaies I see at the Fortune, and Red Bull, where I learne all the words I speake and vnderstand not.

In this play, performed at Cambridge, the clown Trinculo tells how he will woo his lady, Armellina, with foolish phrases drawn from plays performed at the Red Bull. English Professional Theatre, p 570 notes that ‘other instances in which sophisticates mock what was said on the stage of the Red Bull’ appear in Bentley, Jacobean and Caroline Stage, vol 4, pp 241–3.

body.head: sig B2 (Against the Fortune and Curtain playhouses)

ab.note: d Of βλίτοϛ an unsauory hearbe, in English called Beets. Erasmmus Apophthegm.

div.p: I will not particularize those d Blitea dramata (as Laberius termesanother sort) those Fortune-fatted fooles, and Times Ideots, whose garbe is the Tooch-ache of witte, the Plague-sore of Iudgement, the Common-sewer of Obscænities, and the very Traine-powder that dischargeth the roaring Meg (not Mol) of all scurrile villanies vpon the Cities face; who are faine to produce blinde * Impudence to personate himselfe vpon their stage, be hung with chaynes of Garlicke, as an Antidote against their owne infectious breaths, lest it should kill their Oyster-crying Audience. * Vos quoque, and you also, who with Scylla-barking, Stentor-throated bellowings, flashchoaking squibbes of absurd vanities into the nosthrils of your spectators; barbarously diuerting Nature, and defacing Gods owne image, by metamorphosing humane * shape into bestiall forme

Those also stand within the stroke of my penne, who were wont to Curtaine ouer their defects with knauish conueyances, and scum off the froth of all wanton vanity, to qualifie the eager appetite of their slapping Fauourites these are they, who by their wontonizing Stage -gestures, can ingle and seduce men to heaue vp their heartes and affections

div.ab: The reference in the margin to ‘ Greene’s baboon,' is an allusion to a part played by Thomas Green, who had also held the lease on the Curtain playhouse. The author earlier bewails the ‘sin-swelled theatres ’ and that ‘More have recourse to playing houses, than to praying houses,’ (sig. B1v). ‘ [R]oaring Meg (not Mol)’ is probably a reference to Thomas Dekker’s play, The Roaring Girl; ‘Garlicke,’an actor at the Fortune playhouse; and ‘Tu quo,’ a reference to John Cook’s play, Greene’s Tu Quoque.

Proudly. What d’ee this afternoone.
Feesimple. Faith I haue agreat mind to see long-megg and the ship at the Fortune
sig E3v

Drawer. Gentlemen, I beseech you consider where you are, Turne-bole streete , a ciuill place, do not disturbe a number of poore Gentlewomen
Bots. Will you fetch vs wine?
Whoore-bang. And a whoore ( sirrah)
Drawer. Why what d’ee thinke of me, am I an Infidell, a Turke, a Pagan, a Sarazin? I have beene at Besse Turnups, and she sweares all the Gentlewomen went to see a Play at the Fortune, and are not come in yet, and she believes they sup with the Players.

It is likely that two titles are referred to in this passage: ‘ long-megg’ being Long Mege of Westmester, performed by the Admiral’s Men at Newington in 1594 and later. The ‘ ship’ may have been either a jig or part of a double bill; if the former, this is the only evidence that the title of the jig to be performed could be announced beforehand. Possibly there is an allusion to drunks imagining themselves on a rolling ship. (See Baskerville, Jigs, pp 300-1). Evidence suggests that the play was written earlier than its first publication, in 1618, probably in 1612 (William Perry, The Plays of Nathan Field (Austin, Texas, 1950), pp 143-5, 276-7). Nathan Field (1587–1620), player and dramatist, was the son of the puritanical preacher John Field. Turnmill Street is in Clerkenwell.

Another will fore-tell of Lightning and Thunder that shall happen such a day, when there are no such Inflamations seene, except men goe to the Fortune in Golding-lane, to see the Tragedie of Doctor Faustus. There indeede a man may behold shagge-hayr’d Deuills runne roaring ouer the Stage with Squibs in their mouthes, while Drummers make Thunder in the Tyring-house, and the twelue-penny Hirelings make artificiall Lightning in their Heauens.
' Astrologaster' was the name for a fraudulent astrologer.

body.head: sig D2 (Mock almanac concerning the Fortune and Phoenix playhouses)

ab.note: * Præstat fortunatum, quam sapere. Præstatsapere: 'It is better to be lucky than to be wise'
* Auri sacra fames, quid non mortalia pectora coget? Auricoget?: 'To what does the accursed hunger for gold not drive mortal hearts?'; Vergil, Aeneid 3.56—7 Virgilius

div.ab: The Dugges of this delicate young bed fellow to the Sunne, will so flow with the milke of Profit and Plenty; that (of all other) Some Players (if * Fortune, turned PhŒnix, faile not of her promise) will lie sucking at them with their fulsome forcastings, for pence and two-pences, like young * Pigges at a Sow newly farrowed, for that theyare in danger to meet with a hard Winter, and be forced to trauell softly on the hoofe.
sigs Iv–I2* ( Curtain and Red Bull playhouses)

About this time, new Playes will be more in request, then old: and, if company come currant to the Bull and Curtaine, there will be more mo- ney
ney ney: also printed as a catchword at the foot of Iv gathered in one after-noone, then will be giuen to King-sland Spittle in a whole moneth. Also, if at this time, about the houres of foure and fiue, it waxe cloudy, and then raine downe-right, they shall sit dryer in the Galleries, then those who are the vnderstanding men in the yard.
Kingsland hospital here is probably that provided for lepers.

title.name: A Briefe Description of the Notorious Life of John Lambe

div.ab:
Vpon Friday being the 13. of Iune, in the yeare of our Lord 1628. hee went to see a Play at the Fortune, where the boyes of the towne, and other vnruly people hauing obserued him present, after the Play was ended, flocked about him and (after the manner of the common people, who follow a Hubbubb, when it is once a foote) began in a confused manner to assault him, and offer violence. He in affright made towards the Citie as fast as he could out of the fields, and hired a com-
company company: com- printed as a catchword at the foot of C3v of Sailors, who were there present to be his guard. But so great was the furie of the people, who pelted him with stones, and other things which came next to hand, that the Sailors (although they did their endeauour for him) had much adoe to bring him in safetie as farr as Moore-gate. The rage of the people about that place increased so much, that the Sailors for their owne safetie, were forced to leaue the protection of him; and then the multitude pursued him through Coleman-street to the old Iurie , no house being able, nor daring to giue him protection, though hee had attempted many. Foure Constables were there raised to appease the tumult; who all too late for his safety brought him to the Counter in the Poultrey , where he was bestowed vppon the command of the Lord Maior. For before hee was brought thither, the people had had him downe, and with stones and cudgels, and other weapons had so beaten him that no part was left to receiue a wound. Whereupon (although the Surgeons in vaine were sent for) hee neuer spoke a word, but lay languishing vntill Eight a clocke the next morning, and then dyed.

Dr John Lambe was an astrologer patronised by the unpopular duke of Buckingham. Lambe had led a scandalous life, culminating in the rape of a young girl, for which however he was pardoned. The ‘unruly people’ noted here are also named as apprentices (English Professional Theatre, p 643). Bentley, Jacobean and Caroline Stage, vol 6, p 162, gives Sir Francis Nethersole in the account of the affair which he wrote to the queen of Bohemia, CSP Domestic, 1628-9, p 169. There was also a popular ballad, ‘The Tragedy of Doctor Lambe’ (H.E. Rollins,
A Pepysian Garland, p 280).

* two olde Play-houses being also lately reedified, enlarged, and one * new Theatre erected, the multitude of our London Play-haunters being so augmented now, that all the ancient Divels Chappels (for so the Fathers stile all Playhouses) being five in number, are not sufficient to containe their troopes, whence wee see a sixth now added to them
sigs Ddd3v–Ddd4* (The playhouses)

ref.foreign: Idem vere Theatrum, idem & prostibutumprostibulum, prostibutum: for prostibulum eo quod post ludos exactos meretrices ibi prosternantur.

note.note: Idemprosternantur: 'Truly the theatre and brothel are the same thing because after the plays have been acted, harlots are there prostrated'

cit.bibl: H. Rabanus Maurus, De Vniverso . liber 20. capitulum 36.
Chrysostomus Homilia .7. in Matthum Tomus 2 Columna 59. B C. & Homilia 8 De Paenitentia Tomus 5. Columna 750, 751.
Alexander Fabritius Destructio Vitiorum pars 4. capitulum 23.
Bulengerus De Theatro liber 1. capitulum 50 paginae 296. 297.
Bulengerus De Theatro. liber 1. capitulum 50. paginae 296. 297.
Haymo & AnselmeAnselmus Anselme: for Anselmus, in Ephesiorum Capitulum 5. versus 3. accordingly.

Bulengerus, De Theatro.
liber capitulum 1. 50. liber 1. capitulum 50.
liber50.: for liber 1. capitulum 50. (?) paginae 296. 297, 298.

ab.note: mSee the 3. Blast of Retrait from Stage-playes, & BB. Babingions Exposition on the 7. Commandement, accordingly.
n M. Gosson, in his Schoole of Abuses, & Playes Confuted : and the 3. Blast of Retrait from Stage-playes , write thus. See Act 4. Scene 1 .

* Ejusmodi itaque patronos habet ars Lemonia, quique tueantur artem meretriciam, cui in hunc usque diem proh dolor in Christiana republica locus est, & in Civitatibus publica Theatra, immunitates & stipendia concessa sunt, &c. Ejusmodi&c.: 'And so the Lemonian art has patrons of this sort, and who watch over the harlot’s art, for which, to this day, for shame, there is place in the Christian republic, and (to which) in the cities public theatres, privileges, and stipends have been granted'
Agrippa , De Vanitate Scientiae. capitulum 64.

div.ab:
It i was the use of ancient times among the Greekes and Romans, after their Playes were ended, for whores to prostitute themselves to the lusts of others, either on, or under the Theaters where their Playes were acted; the same place being both a Play-house, and a Stewe; k whence both the Brothel-house and the word Fornication, derive their etymology and originall from the Play-house, where Whores l were harboured and trained up as first, till they were confined to the Stewes. How farre this usage yet continues I cannot positively determine; yet this I have heard by good intelligence; that our common Strumpets and Adulteresses after our Stage-playes ended, m are oft-times prostituted neere our Play-houses, if not in them: that our Theaters if they are not Bawdy-houses, (as they may easily be, since many Players , n if reports be true, are common Panders,) yet they
are Cosin-germanes, at * leastwise neighbours to them: Witnesse the Cock-pit, and Drury-lane: Black-friers Play-house, and Duke-humfries; the Red-bull, and Turnball-street: the Globe, and Bank-side Brother-houses, with others of this nature: Such is the vertue of our Playes, our Play-houses

This is the only specific record suggesting the rebuilding or enlargement of the Red Bull in the 1620s, although the dating is imprecise. Histrio Mastix was published in 1633, but it had been entered on the Stationers’ Register on 16 October 1630, and parts were probably written earlier, perhaps in 1625. The whole of Prynne’s tract is a Puritan polemic against players, stage plays, and theatres. He was at one time imprisoned for his writings.

I myselfe did know one Thomas Vincent that was a Book-keeper or prompter at the Globe play-house neere the Banck-end in Maid-lane: As also I did know Iohn Singer, who
play'd
playd playd: play’d printed as a catchword at the foot of E4v the Clownes part at the Fortune-play-house in Golding-Lane, these two men had such strange and different humours.

These references to two men, Thomas Vincent at the Globe, and John Singer at the Fortune, are mentioned in the seventeenth anecdote in Taylor’s pamphlet of 1638 (entered into the Stationers’ Register in 1637). The story itself is an old one with new names, but Taylor’s association of Vincent with the player John Singer, who was dead before 1608, suggests that the former was prompter at the Globe in its early days (Bentley, Jacobean and Caroline Stage, vol 2, p 612).

Scorne then their censures, who gav’t out, thy Witt
As long upon a ComŒdie did fit
As Elephants bring forth; and that thy blotts
And mendings tooke more time then Fortune plots:
sig E4

Thrift. And I will hasten to the money Box,
And take my shilling out again, for now
I have considered that it is too much;
I’le go to th’ Bull, or Fortune, and there see
A Play for two pense, with a Jig to boot. Exit.

The ‘Praeludium’ at the start of the play was set on the stage of the Salisbury Court playhouse, with Bolt, a door-keeper, sitting with a box to one side, up to whom comes Thrift, a citizen. After hearing that it will cost a shilling to come in (sig B), Thrift decides this was too much, and that he would go to the Red Bull or Fortune , where seats were cheaper, probably only a groat.

title.name: A Second Discovery by the Northern Scout

div.p:
In the meane time let me tell ye a lamentable Tragedie, acted by the Prelacie, against the poore Players of the Fortune Play-house, which made them sing
Fortune my foe why dust thou frowne on me? &c.
or having gotten a new old Play, called The Cardinalls Conspiracie , whoe they brought upon the Stage in as great state as they could, with Altars, Images, Crosses,Crucifixes , and the like, to set forth his pomp and pride. But wofull was the sign to see, how in the middest of all their mirth, the
Pu ersevants
Puesevants: first e for r came and seazed upon the poore Cardinall, and all his Consorts, and carried them away. And when they were questioned for it, in the high Commission Court, they pleaded Ignorance, and told the Archbishop, thus they tooke those examples of their Altars, Images, and the like from Heathen Authors. This did somewhat asswage his anger, that they did not bring him on the Stage : but yet they were fined for it, and after a little imprisonment got their liberty. And having nothing left them but a few old Swords, and Bucklers, they fell to act the valiant Scot, which they played five dayes with great applause, which vext the Bishops worse than the other, insomuch that they were forbidden playing any more, and some of them prohibited ever Playing againe.

Well (quouth Willie) let the Bishops be angry as they will, we have acted the valiant Scot bravely at Barwicke, and if ever J live to come to London, Ile make one myselfe to make up the number, that it may be acted there too, and that with a new action, for I can tell thee, here’s matter enough, and ye ken that I can Fence bravely slish slash with the best of them.

div.ab: Even before the closing of the theatres in 1642, the playhouses had showed poor judgement by offending both state and church, for which they were often fined. The mention of swords and bucklers, and of fencing on stage, recalls the ‘prizes,’ the trials of arms held by fencers at city and suburban playhouses in the late 16th century (see Hotson, Commonwealth and Restoration Stage, pp 3-7, 71). The episode also appears in Vox Borealis, probably by Richard Overton, published in 1640-1. The Valiant Scot by J.W. had been published in 1637 but can be dated to about 1626. In this context the allusions are to Charles I’s unsuccessful actions against the Scots in the Bishops’ Wars (the first Bishops’ War ended in June 1639, and a Second followed when England was invaded by the Scots in August 1640; the king’s army was defeated within a week) (Randall, Winter Fruit, pp 20, 22-3).

But if you needs must write, if poverty
So pinch, that otherwise you starve and die,
On Gods name may the Bull or Cockpit have
Your lame blancke Verse, to keepe you from the grave:
Or let new Fortunes younger brethren see,
What they can picke from your leane industry.

ab.hi: A Prologue spoken upon removing of the late Fortune Players to the Bull.

div.ab:
WHo would rely on Fortune, when shee’s knowne
An enemie to Merit, and hath shewne
Such an example here? Wee that have pay’d
Her tribute to our losse, each night defray’d
The charge of her attendance, now growne poore,
(Through her expences) thrusts us out of doore,
For some peculiar profit; shee has t’ane
A course to banish Modesty, and retaine
More dinn, and incivility than hath been
Knowne in the Bearward Court, the Beargarden.
Those that now sojourne with her, bring a noyse
Of Rables, Apple-wives and Chimney-boyes,
Whose shrill confused Ecchoes loud doe cry,
Enlarge your Commons, Wee hate Privacie.
Those that have plots to undermine, and strive
To blow their Neighbours up, so they may thrive,
What censure they deserve, wee leave to you,
To whom the judgement on’t belongs as due.
Here Gentlemen, our Anchor’s fixt; And wee
(Disdaining Fortune’s mutability)
Expect your kinde acceptance; then wee’l sing
(Protected by your smiles our ever-spring;)
As pleasant as if wee had still possest
Our lawful portion out of Fortune’s brest:
Onely
Onely Onely: also printed as a catchword at the foot of H2v wee would request you to forbeare
Your wonted custome, banding Tyle, or Peare,
Against our curtaines, to allure us forth.
I pray take notice these are of more Worth,
Pure Naples silk, not Worstead; we have ne’re
An Actour here has mouth enough to teare
Language by th’eares; this forlone Hope shall be
By Us refin’d from such grosse injury.
And then let your judicious Loves advance
Vs to our Merits, them to their Ignorance.

title.name: Petition and Articles Exhibited against Dr Fuller

div.ab:
THE PETITION AND ARTICLES EXHIBITED Against DR FVLLER
Vicar of S. Giles Cripple-gate against Timothy Hutton, Curate of the said Parish who preferred the Play-house and the Taverns before the performance of their Office in the Church
sig A3v

9 The said Dr Fuller hath so ill provided for this so great a Parish , that besides much other disservice: there having certaine Parishioners attended to see the christian buriall of a dead corps, could neither find the said Doctor or his Curate, though having notice before thereof: after that also, another Corps, then a third, all attending in the church yard, And at the last; hearing that Timothy Hutton his Curate, was at the Fortune to see a Play , they sent to desire him, to officiate for the three corps: but hee would by no meanes come; then they sent a second, and a third time also, certifying how long they had there waited: yet would the said Timothy Hutton by no meanes come, until such time that the play was ended.

title.name: The Last Will and Testament of Doctors Commons

div.ab: I Doctors Commons doe make, constitute, and ordaine this my last Will and Testament, in manner & forme following, that is to say.
sig A3
Item, all my Bookes of Acts, I will and bequeath to the Fortune and Bull Play-House, for they want good action.
sig A3v

for witnesse whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and seale, this 23 of Iune, 1641.
Signed, sealed, and published, in the
presence of us I. L. A. D.
and T. E. and many other
credible witnesses.
FINIS.

title.name: The Late Will and Testament of the Doctors Commons

div.ab: I Doctors Commons, in the Parish of S. Benedicts Pauls-Wharf, London, declare and make this my last will and Testament Item, I will and bequeath all my large Bookes of Acts, to them of the Fortune Play-House, for I hold it a deed of charity, in regard they want good action; In Witnesse whereof, I the said Doctors Commons have hereunto set my hand and Seale this 26 June, in the yeare of our Lord, 1641.

Signed, sealed, published, and declared in the Presence of
W. C.
R. P.
B. K.
